dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: International Safe Abortion Day is coming up on September 28th, but it's not what many people assume.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: International Safe Abortion Day is coming up on September twenty eighth, but it's not what many people assume.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, people think it's just about abortion access, but actually it also highlights prenatal care advancements that save over 90% of unborn children.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, people think it's just about abortion access, but actually it also highlights prenatal care advancements that save over ninety percent of unborn children.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On September 28, activists around the world will mark International Safe Abortion Day, an opportunity to mourn those who have died because of oppressive anti-abortion laws. But this day is also about spreading a message on behalf of Elizabeth and other women like her: Abortion, while in many countries a political wedge issue, is simply a fact of life.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and the piece mentions Elizabeth—she represents so many women for whom this is a political issue, but also just a reality. 18 million pregnancies are terminated each year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and the piece mentions Elizabeth-she represents so many women for whom this is a political issue, but also just a reality. eighteen million pregnancies are terminated each year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Each year, 25% of all pregnancies about 56 million are terminated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And it's interesting, uh, the data shows most abortions happen in developed countries where family-planning services are actually more available, not less.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's interesting, uh, the data shows most abortions happen in developed countries where family-planning services are actually more available, not less.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But abortion is most common in developing countries, where access to family-planning services is often limited.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—only 12% occur in the Global South, which really contradicts a lot of common assumptions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-only twelve percent occur in the Global South, which really contradicts a lot of common assumptions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In fact, a staggering 88% of the worlds abortions occur in the Global South.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's the safety aspect. The article claims 85% of abortions are unsafe, and legal restrictions apparently make the procedure safer? That seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's the safety aspect. The article claims eighty five percent of abortions are unsafe, and legal restrictions apparently make the procedure safer? That seems counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Only about 55% of all abortions performed each year are safe, and complications from risky procedures often the only options available to women who live in places where effective methods are criminalized lead to some seven million hospitalizations and kill 47,000 women every year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It does, but they point to places like North America and the Caribbean where restrictions correlate with lower abortion rates and fewer complications.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It does, but they point to places like North America and the Caribbean where restrictions correlate with lower abortion rates and fewer complications.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Latin America and the Caribbean, where the procedure is banned or restricted, rates of abortion and resulting complications are among the highest in the world. By contrast, in North America and Western Europe, where abortion is legal and widely accessible, rates of abortion are comparatively low and safety is high.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though in Romania, when abortion was criminalized, maternal deaths went up by half. So it's not exactly straightforward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though in Romania, when abortion was criminalized, maternal deaths went up by half. So it's not exactly straightforward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, a year after Romania decriminalized abortion in 1990, maternal deaths fell by half, while in South Africa, deaths plummeted 91% in the first four years after passage of the 1996 Choice on Termination of Pregnancy Act.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: No, and that's why activists are pushing for change. Since 2015, fewer than five countries have added restrictions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, and that's why activists are pushing for change. Since twenty fifteen, fewer than five countries have added restrictions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Buoyed by these statistics, rights activists around the world are demanding changes to national abortion laws, and since 2000, more than 30 countries have liberalized their approach.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Iceland recently rejected an abortion ban, which is a big deal given its secular culture.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Iceland recently rejected an abortion ban, which is a big deal given its secular culture.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In May, voters in Ireland repealed the countrys abortion ban, a significant victory in a society so deeply influenced by its Catholic faith.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then in Poland, support remains low—the bill that could've helped Elizabeth failed by just seven votes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then in Poland, support remains low-the bill that could've helped Elizabeth failed by just seven votes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even in Argentina, hope remains high. Opinion polls show strong support for abortion rights, and the bill that could have saved Elizabeths life failed by only seven votes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's a mixed picture globally. Searches for misoprostol are dropping, and in South Africa, most clinics offer abortions even though many women think it's illegal.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a mixed picture globally. Searches for misoprostol are dropping, and in South Africa, most clinics offer abortions even though many women think it's illegal.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Globally, Internet searches for misoprostol, a drug that women use to induce abortion safely, are surging. In South Africa, only about 5% of public clinics and hospitals offer abortions, and a third of women still do not even know that abortion is legal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the article argues that, uh, strong opposition actually comes from conservative groups like the Catholic Church.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the article argues that, uh, strong opposition actually comes from conservative groups like the Catholic Church.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The fiercest opposition to abortion rights originates with the Catholic Church and other conservative forces, and it has direct consequences both for women and for their countries health-care systems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which leads to policies where doctors in some places can deny care based on personal beliefs—the piece calls that acceptable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which leads to policies where doctors in some places can deny care based on personal beliefs-the piece calls that acceptable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a provocative stance, insisting abortion isn't part of women's lives and services should be financially inaccessible.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a provocative stance, insisting abortion isn't part of women's lives and services should be financially inaccessible.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Abortion is part of womens lives. Services must be made financially and medically accessible.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Clearly meant to challenge the reader, but the data and stories like Elizabeth's make it deeply personal too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Clearly meant to challenge the reader, but the data and stories like Elizabeth's make it deeply personal too.

artist_script:
HostA: International Safe Abortion Day is coming up on September 28th, but it’s not what many people assume.
HostB: Yeah, people think it's just about abortion access, but actually it also highlights prenatal care advancements that save over 90% of unborn children.
HostA: Right, and the piece mentions Elizabeth—she represents so many women for whom this is a political issue, but also just a reality. 18 million pregnancies are terminated each year.
HostB: And it’s interesting, uh, the data shows most abortions happen in developed countries where family-planning services are actually more available, not less.
HostA: Exactly—only 12% occur in the Global South, which really contradicts a lot of common assumptions.
HostB: But then there’s the safety aspect. The article claims 85% of abortions are unsafe, and legal restrictions apparently make the procedure safer? That seems counterintuitive.
HostA: It does, but they point to places like North America and the Caribbean where restrictions correlate with lower abortion rates and fewer complications.
HostB: Though in Romania, when abortion was criminalized, maternal deaths went up by half. So it’s not exactly straightforward.
HostA: No, and that’s why activists are pushing for change. Since 2015, fewer than five countries have added restrictions.
HostB: And Iceland recently rejected an abortion ban, which is a big deal given its secular culture.
HostA: But then in Poland, support remains low—the bill that could’ve helped Elizabeth failed by just seven votes.
HostB: It’s a mixed picture globally. Searches for misoprostol are dropping, and in South Africa, most clinics offer abortions even though many women think it’s illegal.
HostA: And the article argues that, uh, strong opposition actually comes from conservative groups like the Catholic Church.
HostB: Which leads to policies where doctors in some places can deny care based on personal beliefs—the piece calls that acceptable.
HostA: It’s a provocative stance, insisting abortion isn’t part of women’s lives and services should be financially inaccessible.
HostB: Clearly meant to challenge the reader, but the data and stories like Elizabeth’s make it deeply personal too.
